newsitem.title: INDONESIA: INDONESIA C.BANK GOVERNOR CALLS MOVE A FREE FLOAT.
newsitem.headline: INDONESIA C.BANK GOVERNOR CALLS MOVE A FREE FLOAT.

text.p: Indonesian central bank governor Sudradjad Djiwandono said on Thursday that the lifting of the bank's intervention band implied a free float of the rupiah although it reserved the right to intervene if needed.

"Theoretically, it's a free float," he told Reuters Financial Television in an interview. "But of course Bank Indonesia would like to intervene to keep developments on course, to smooth the adaptment period.
"Our job as the monetary authority is to provide a good climate for the business sector," he said.
Djiwandono said that the move had led to rapid falls in the rupiah but he hoped the currency would level off.
"We hope it will lead to a new equilibrium," he said. "The equilibrium may not be a fixed point, it could be an area."
He added that the decision to do away with the intervention band was taken with careful consideration.
"It does not mean we are going haywire," he said.
Djiwandono also said there would be no move to introduce exchange controls on the rupiah.
"Why should we control?" he said when asked if there was a possibility of any such move."
He said the float of the rupiah was in response to similar moves undertaken by the Philippines and Thailand in recent weeks.
"We are a regional market now. We are moving together," Djiwandono said.
"In the last few weeks Indonesia is the only one which had a band, it's the only one defending the rupiah," he said adding that maintaining that position would be more and more difficult.
"We are adjusting to the new realities," he said. "The new reality in the ASEAN (Association of South East Asian Nations) region is floating (currencies)."
